wordAnalysis.meaning: in knowledge, here: in deity worship

translations.text: Into blinding darkness enter those who worship ignorance (karma), and into still greater darkness, as it were, those who delight in knowledge (of deities).
Into blinding darkness enter those who worship ignorance; and into still greater darkness, as it were, those who are devoted to knowledge alone.

bhashya.sanskrit:
अन्धं तमः अदर्शनात्मकं तमः प्रविशन्ति । के ? ये अविद्याम् , विद्याया अन्या अविद्या कर्मेत्यर्थः, कर्मणो विद्याविरोधित्वात् , तामविद्यामग्निहोत्रादिलक्षणामेव केवलाम् उपासते तत्पराः सन्तोऽनुतिष्ठन्तीत्यभिप्रायः । ततः तस्मादन्धात्मकात्तमसः भूय इव बहुतरमेव ते तमः प्रविशन्ति । के ? कर्म हित्वा ये उ ये तु विद्यायामेव देवताज्ञाने एव रताः अभिरताः ॥

[Continuation]
तत्रावान्तरफलभेदं विद्याकर्मणोः समुच्चयकारणमाह । अन्यथा फलवदफलवतोः संनिहितयोरङ्गाङ्गितया जामितैव स्यादिति —
keyPoints: Avidyā here means karma (rituals like agnihotra), not metaphysical ignorance
Vidyā here means knowledge/worship of deities (devatājñāna), not Brahman-knowledge
Those who worship karma alone (without vidyā) enter blind darkness
Those who abandon karma and are devoted only to deity-knowledge enter even greater darkness
This condemns exclusive practice (ekaikānuṣṭhāna) of either, not the practices themselves
The condemnation is due to the desire for combination (samuccicīṣā) - doing both together
Neither karma nor deity-knowledge should be practiced exclusively
Both have separate results: karma leads to pitṛ-loka, vidyā to deva-loka (per Bṛ.Up. 1.5.16)
Scripture-enjoined practices cannot be dismissed as not-to-be-done (akartavya)
Supreme Self-knowledge (ātmaikatva-vijñāna) cannot be combined with karma or other knowledge
This teaching is for those still desirous (kāmin), not for desireless renunciates (akāmin)
Foundation for teaching samuccaya (combination) in subsequent mantras
bhashya.notes:
Śaṅkara Bhagavadpāda's commentary establishes that avidyā here specifically means karma (rituals like agnihotra), not metaphysical ignorance, while vidyā means upāsanā (deity-meditation) leading to deva-loka, not supreme Brahman-knowledge. The condemnation is not of these practices themselves - both are śāstra-vihita (scripture-enjoined) with their own legitimate fruits (pitṛ-loka for karma, deva-loka for vidyā per Bṛ.Up. 1.5.16). Rather, what is condemned is exclusive practice (ekaikānuṣṭhāna) of either one alone.

The verse teaches that those who practice karma exclusively without vidyā enter blind darkness, while those who abandon karma and practice only vidyā enter even greater darkness. This establishes the foundation for the samuccaya teaching in subsequent mantras - that karma and vidyā should be combined appropriately. This teaching is specifically for householders who still have desires (kāmin), not for the desireless renunciates (akāmin) established in Self-knowledge for whom such combination is impossible and unnecessary.

centralTeaching: Exclusive devotion to either karma (rituals) alone or upāsanā (deity-meditation) alone leads to darkness. Neither should be practiced in isolation - they must be combined appropriately for those qualified householders who cannot yet take up the path of renunciation and Self-knowledge.

coreConcepts.definition: Here specifically means karma (Vedic rituals like agnihotra), not metaphysical ignorance; opposed to vidyā
Here specifically means knowledge/worship of deities (devatājñāna), not supreme Brahman-knowledge
Combination, synthesis; the teaching that karma and upāsanā should be combined, not practiced exclusively
Knowledge of deities; meditation on various deities, leading to their worlds but not to liberation

relatedVerses.note: Explains that vidyā and avidyā have different results, justifying their combination
Shows how to combine both - crossing death through avidyā, attaining immortality through vidyā
Earlier established karma-niṣṭhā for householders; this expands on that teaching
